thread.title: Earthquake with magnitude of 3.9 hits North Sea off the coast of Yorkshire
thread.title_full: Earthquake with magnitude of 3.9 hits North Sea off the coast of Yorkshire

author: Sophie Jamieson
title: Earthquake with magnitude of 3.9 hits North Sea off the coast of Yorkshire
text:
Earthquake with magnitude of 3.9 hits North Sea off the coast of Yorkshire The earthquake hit off the coast of Yorkshire Credit: Alamy / Loop Images Ltd 3 January 2017 • 10:09pm 
A n earthquake has hit the North Sea off the coast of North Yorkshire. 
It had a magnitude of 3.9 on the Richter scale and struck shortly before 7pm on Tuesday night, 100 miles east of Scarborough. 
B ritish Geological Survey seismologists recorded the quake on devices located in Glasidale near Whitby. 
There have been no reports of the earthquake having been felt by people on land. For more info on UK #earthquakes including their size, frequency and possible causes then see our website https://t.co/sf2AhWpzDa — BGS (@BritGeoSurvey) January 3, 2017 
A n earthquake of a magnitude of 4 occurs in Britain on average every two years. The North Sea is more active for earthquakes than the mainland of Britain. 
In May 2015, people in Kent felt tremors as an earthquake measuring 4.2 on the Richter scale struck in the middle of the night. It was the biggest earthquake in Britain for seven years. 
The largest recorded British earthquake was in 1931, near the Dogger Bank in the North Sea. Although it was 60 miles off shore, the 6.1 magnitude earthquake still caused some damage to buildings on land. Follow Telegraph News
